text: Hi, everyone. In this lesson, we're going to go ahead and take a look at the newest way to create layered materials in Unreal. So let's get started. In my slides, you'll see that I have broken down every single step that you need to take to be able to make this process work. There are three major materials that you're going to need. You're going to need a material layer. You're also going to need a material in general as a parent material to house everything. And you're also going to need a material library setup. And in that material library setup within your material, we need to create a thing called a blend material. And that blend asset is going to make it so that we can actually bring the two materials together. So let's go and jump into Unreal and feel free to follow along with the slides. And we're going to break this down so you can see exactly the steps to make it happen. So in Unreal, we can see that I have set up here a layered material system and it says the new way. I have two different version copies here that you can actually look at. And they're doing two different things. One of them is a simple two layer blend. The other one is a three layer blend. And any time you can click on these and crack them open, we're mainly going to focus on the two layer blend just for time sake. But we can also look at this one first up and see kind of what's going on under the hood. If I click on this one, let's go and click on the material here inside the details. So I double click that. Let me go and pull this one over. And we'll see that we actually have the details as well as the layer parameters. Now, we've actually added a while back the ability to be able to add the layers if you need to. And you can create an instant material layer and in here, connect the materials that maybe you've already built. You'll see a plus sign for that here. Down below, we see that we have an ice material. Took a while to populate, but I got in there. And this ice material is our layer asset. In this particular case, you'll see that ML is underneath because I've made this into a material layer. I'll show you how to do that in just a bit. And down below, we have several different areas from which everything is pop everything is populated. We'll see under our subsurface area, which is built within the ice. We have a subsurface amount and a subsurface color, which is exposed. But in there, we also have an MLB, which is a material layer blend. This material layer blend allows these other materials, such as this one on the top and this one on the bottom, to all actually blend together. And you'll see there is one more here at the bottom also. So these allow us to be able to actually have three different layers of materials in here. And really, the key is these material layer blends. If they're in place, they're going to allow everything to come together. Now we're going to do this a more in a simpler aspect or a simple way. We're going to go ahead and tackle this with a more simple here. I'm clicking on the one from behind back here. And this one, if we get to our layer properties, we're going to be building the material in this particular case. Now, I made a couple in here in the default that have populated and they're not actually going to do anything. So we can actually get rid of them or you can keep them if you want to and throw some stuff in there later. But we're going to first build our material layers one into and then we're going to make a single material layer blend. And they're going to cause these guys to actually blend together. So how it's going to look if we went in here and played with it and I'll keep this material instance open, you can actually see I have an area underneath our scale of parameter values. I haven't grouped this one, but you get the idea of grouping. We can go in here and I can contrast it, pull up the contrast and you'll see the details of the damage come through. If I go to intensity, I can see that I can actually completely get rid of it and make the tile come through from the bottom. This is really convenient and helpful. And that's pretty much what we're going to build. So let's go and jump right in and do so. All right. So let's go ahead and build our first material. That's just to keep things up up and running here. And we're going to make a new one called M.L. underscore new tile and then M.L.s for material layer. Now, if you're not sure how to get there, you simply right click in here, go to materials and you should know this by now to get to the erroneous stuff. There's the broken down normals. Cool. Got that set up. And we, in this particular case, we can go straight into the normals. Now, if you wanted to, you can elaborate this a little bit more. Put this in the A channel and then we'll drag this into the base color. Grab the normal put into the A channel. Put the scalar into the B channel and grab that input into the normal. And there we go.
